title: Researchers create a digital twin to run DAWN, Synhelion's solar fuels plant - SolarPACES
description:
Speed matters for real-time simulation Now that Synhelion is beginning its first commercial production of solar fuels, plant operators will need to adapt to changing information in real time.
The studies are to validate physics-based and machine-learning-based models for simulating DAWN’s solar fuel plant operation.
Synhelion’s high-temperature solid thermal energy storage system uses ceramic refractory bricks with internal channels to carry the heat transfer fluid.
However, both provide a solid base for building a digital twin of the solar fuel process.
Synhelion has now delivered its first solar aviation fuel to SWISS World’s first solar jet fuel plant inaugurated by Synhelion
text:
Collaborating with Synhelion engineers, a solar research team at the Solar-Institute Jülich (SIJ) of FH Aachen presented two papers at SolarPACES 2025 assessing the accuracy and reliability of dynamic process models for a solar fuel production system. They used operating data from Synhelion’s DAWN pilot plant.

In Synhelion’s solar fuel plant, DAWN, concentrated solar power drives endothermic chemical reactions to convert biogenic methane, carbon dioxide, and steam into synthesis gas (syngas), which can then be processed into liquid hydrocarbon fuels, such as kerosene for aviation or gasoline.

Because the methane and carbon is derived from bio-waste rather than fossil fuels, and heat is generated from concentrated solar heat instead of burning fossil fuels, Synhelion is pioneering a sustainable drop-in replacement for today’s liquid fuels.

Synhelion’s DAWN pilot plant in Jülich (which can be toured at the next SolarPACES conference in the Fall of 2026) uses RED-certified sustainable biogenic waste as the methane and carbon source and has demonstrated the complete production chain under real solar operation conditions.

Synhelion’s solar-absorbing gas receiver is a unique design that is capable of extremely efficient conversion of solar irradiance from the heliostats to temperatures as high as 1500°C.

How can Synhelion’s solar receiver achieve such high temperatures?

Speed matters for real-time simulation

Now that Synhelion is beginning its first commercial production of solar fuels, plant operators will need to adapt to changing information in real time. Traditional physics-based models can be fast, but that usually comes at the cost of lower accuracy. So the team took a new approach.

“We needed a system where we can offer simulation results in real time to aid the operators who run the plant and make the decisions,” explained lead author Falko Schneider in a call from SIJ in Germany.

“For example, when to switch operation modes, what kind of mass flows or compositions of the reactants to set. To achieve this, we need models that can deliver both high accuracy and high computational speed. You can also use the process model offline to test potential operating and control strategies, of course, where speed doesn’t matter as much. The physics-based model takes a bit longer, but still, it’s very fast. It’s not like it needs days to simulate a week of operation.

The studies are to validate physics-based and machine-learning-based models for simulating DAWN’s solar fuel plant operation. The idea is to replace the more computationally expensive physics-based simulations with machine-learning models and validating an efficient alternative. The team first created a machine-learning model of the thermal energy storage with synthetic data from the physics-based model and successfully validated it.

In the overall system study, Validation of a Dynamic Process Model of a Thermochemical System for Solar Fuel Production, all three key components are validated against real-time operation. The key components are the solar receiver, the reforming reactor where the thermochemistry happens, and the thermal energy storage, which is crucial in solar fuels production, as the thermochemistry must operate continuously.

Synhelion’s high-temperature solid thermal energy storage system uses ceramic refractory bricks with internal channels to carry the heat transfer fluid.

The thermal energy storage had the most comprehensive study

The second study, A Validated Machine Learning Approach to Efficient Thermal Energy Storage Simulation Using Synthetic Data, focused on this component, the thermal energy storage. Of the three aspects studied, the thermal storage was most fully modeled.

The thermal energy storage model successfully reproduced charge-discharge transients over 8 cycles across 10 days, achieving errors of less than 3% of the temperature swing in the upper storage layers, although deviations increased toward the bottom due to potential material property variations and mass flow measurement uncertainties.

The team’s surrogate model yielded results in milliseconds on the synthetic validation data, compared with on average over five seconds for a physics-based model—making it roughly 100 to 1000 times faster. On operational validiation data from DAWN, it is even up to 50.000 times faster. Its run times were also much more consistent, allowing the system to run many simulations very quickly, making it practical for optimization tasks or real-time control.

Since solar flux onto the receiver wasn’t directly measured during operation, the researchers developed a simplified data-driven surrogate solar field model using a 4th-degree polynomial with ridge regression.

“We used experimental data as input and compared the output to the experimental data,” Falko explained. “ The coupled surrogate-receiver simulation achieved outlet gas temperatures of approximately 1000°C, showing good agreement with experimental data, although it slightly overestimated temperatures due to a minor systematic bias in the surrogate model. And since then, the receiver has been operated at output temperatures of over 1200°C.

The model validation for the reforming reactor revealed major discrepancies, though. Especially under partial-load conditions, the model overestimated the reaction rate and heat consumption, with residual methane present, contrary to equilibrium predictions, and lower CO₂ conversion than expected.

“We still have some work to do there,” Schneider noted.

“Usually you have these physical models, and then you fit them with operational data. There are components that work very well, right out of the box, without a fitting. The thermal storage model worked quite well already without any fitting. But regarding the chemistry, we need to do some more work. We assumed that a thermochemical equilibrium had been reached within the reactor. That was the statement we got from an industrial manufacturer. However, in the end, it did not align with reality, probably due to the relatively small reactor size.”

So the team needed to implement some kinetics:

“For example, we could implement some factors that allow us to say, ‘Okay, depending on how fast the reactants flow through the catalyst, it will get that close to a thermal chemical equilibrium.’ If it reaches or not, or how close it gets, and what the composition would look like are factors that can be fitted with operational data from DAWN. So this is about the reactor kinetics,” he said.

Work continues on the solar receiver and the reforming reactor

“For the solar receiver, the problem is that we do not have the operational measurements of the concentrated flux hitting it,” he said. “So we are missing an input variable, and we don’t have a detailed model of the heliostat field because a lot of factors go into this. You usually use ray tracing tools to create these kind of models which are not applicable in the process model. So I created this approximation of the heliostat field model, and used that to validate the receiver model. That’s not a strict validation, but at least it’s a successful plausibility check.”

And the reforming reactor model still needs major improvements. It may be necessary to replace the current equilibrium method with a kinetic model or utilize effectiveness factors to more accurately capture how the system behaves under partial loads. However, both provide a solid base for building a digital twin of the solar fuel process.

“Since we are already creating some component models based on machine-learning, we are checking as well if this would be suitable to accurately reproduce the chemistry,” Scheider pointed out.

“This was a publicly funded project between Synhelion, SIJ and Germany’s Institute of Future Fuels at DLR as partners, within which DAWN was built. DLR also created a small lab setup to evaluate different kinds of catalysts. They developed more detailed chemical models with that data. So we are working with them to see whether we can implement it in our model.”

The team’s machine-learning models have been developed within the TwinSF project in the EU, which combines tested physical models with data-driven approaches to help guide operations in alternative fuel production plants using concentrated solar energy to produce sustainable fuels.

The long-term goal is to develop a functioning digital twin that enables real-time plant monitoring, predictive control, and virtual testing of control strategies before they get implemented on an actual solar fuels plant’s system.

Synhelion has now delivered its first solar aviation fuel to SWISS

World’s first solar jet fuel plant inaugurated by Synhelion

title: COP30: Roundup for Day 5 – Nov. 14 - Carbon Pulse
description:
Climate Investment was launched in 2015 by the Oil and Gas Climate Initiative, of which Total is a member.
Research by Fossil Free Politics shows that France, Sweden and Italy had the largest EU fossil fuel delegations out of the other 27 member states.
In total nine EU governments brought 84 fossil fuel lobbyists into COP30 on their official government delegations, out of the 1600 fossil fuel lobbyists present at Belem’s conference.
C40 cities have pledged to halve fossil fuel use by 2030, with the highest-emitting countries moving fastest.
Complementing them is a private-finance-endorsed High-Quality Energy Investment Planning Roadmap, designed to help countries mobilise private capital at scale and accelerate global clean energy deployment.
text:
Day 5 at COP30 in Belem. The humid weather and air conditioning are blowing hot and cold, depending on which corner of the venue you are in, which one delegate quipped was “a bit like the carbon markets” at the moment. Nature and carbon are firmly on Friday’s agenda across side events at the summit, and negotiators on Article 6 were also said to have enjoyed calmer talks on Thursday, though after a new text on crediting Paris projects landed overnight, it now seems reopening adopted work on the new crediting mechanism may be back on the table at the conference.

Timestamps are in local time (GMT-3).

0800 – New texts, new drama: But just when parties were saying they did not intend to create fresh drama at COP30 on Article 6, a new text concerning the Paris Agreement Crediting Mechanism (PACM) dropped. Heavily bracketed, containing provisions around an extended transition of Kyoto-era projects to the new Article 6.4 system, and a proposed extension of current Supervisory Body members’ term limits, one observers said it was “looking really bad”, with some of provisions in the text calling for adopted standards on the PACM, such as on baselines and additionality to possibly to be tweaked. Carbon Pulse will look to analyse in full and publish an update later on Friday.

0900 – You shall not pass: A peaceful protest by Indigenous groups blocked the main entrance to COP30 this morning, with demonstrators calling for a meeting with President Lula and highlighting that major projects – including those related to soy, waterways, and carbon markets – are moving ahead without their free, prior, and informed consent (FPIC). Delegates were redirected to a side entrance, with officials stressing there was no security risk. Commenting from the scene, Cool Earth’s Natalie Klepacova said the action reflected longstanding exclusion and broken promises, adding that Indigenous peoples are rights-holders and frontline defenders whose voices must be central to climate decision-making.

1000 – To Tulio, with love: Building on the Brazilian presidency’s description of negotiations as therapy sessions, where parties should feel encouraged to share their true feelings in a safe space, Brazil’s top COP strategist Tulio Andrade asked delegates on Thursday to send him private “love letters” expressing how they felt the conversations were proceeding – and encouraging those that hadn’t to write soon, according to one negotiator in the room. The presidency extended talks on the four main issues – around the ambition gap, trade, finance, and reporting on progress – until another plenary on Saturday. The plenary is likely to be in the morning, to give the SB chairs time to take stock of talks, but not set yet.

1000 – Whitehouse in the house: US Senator Sheldon Whitehouse (D-RI) is arriving in Belem as the sole representative of the US federal government. The top-ranking Democrat on the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee plans to participate in discussions on Friday on the future of offshore wind, clean shipping, and non-CO2 GHG emissions and hold meetings with international leaders and the private sector.

1030 – Total investment: French oil and gas major TotalEnergies is putting $100 mln into a fund that backs technologies to cut emissions from the oil and gas value chain. Climate Investment’s venture strategy fund has had a portfolio impact of 133 MtCO2e since 2019, particularly in the detection and abatement of methane, carbon capture, and energy efficiency, TotalEnergies said. Climate Investment was launched in 2015 by the Oil and Gas Climate Initiative, of which Total is a member.

1130 – Document development: The Mexican state of Jalisco has submitted its registration document to J-REDD+ standard ART TREES. The document will now undergo a completeness check, and if accepted, will be posted for a public comment period.

1200 – Virtual hugs from US Democrats: US Representative Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) joined the House Sustainable Energy and Environment Coalition as the former Speaker of the House to critique the absence of the Trump administration from the international climate negotiations. Pelosi and other members had planned to attend in Belem but were delayed by the federal shutdown, which ended on Thursday. The House Democrats reaffirmed their commitment to the Paris Agreement.

1330 – Utility upgrades: Utilities around the world plan to up their annual investment in the energy transition to $148 bln per year, from $117 bln, IRENA announced on Friday. The plan, by the members of the Utilities for Net Zero Alliance, will see the companies mobilise over $1 trillion towards the energy investment up to 2030, since the group was established in 2023. Investments will go towards power grids and networks, including $1.24 spent on grids and storage for every $1 spent on renewable generation. It also includes delivering tends of thousands of kilometres of new and upgraded grid infrastructure.

1430 – France and Italy’s red carpet for fossil fuels: While European Commissioner Hoekstra kept his promise and did not bring fossil fuel lobbyists to COP30 as part of his entourage, France and Italy didn’t get the memo, according to NGO Friends of the Earth. Research by Fossil Free Politics shows that France, Sweden and Italy had the largest EU fossil fuel delegations out of the other 27 member states. France brought along five TotalEnergies lobbyists, including CEO Patrick Pouyanne, and sizeable delegations from EDF and ENGIE, for a total of 22 lobbyists. Italy brought along 12 lobbyists, and Sweden 18. In total nine EU governments brought 84 fossil fuel lobbyists into COP30 on their official government delegations, out of the 1600 fossil fuel lobbyists present at Belem’s conference.

1430 – Badgering the State Department: US Sen. Sheldon Whitehouse (D-RI) told reporters in Belem that federal representatives of the US are missing from the international conference as much due to the federal shutdown, as due to complicated logistics. Without the cooperation of the US State Department, the senator said it has been challenging to access the Blue Zone at COP30. In previous years, Whitehouse and other member of Congress have asked the State Department for “party overflow” badges to the US delegation. The State Department denied the request, according to a Whitehouse staffer, as the country had not applied to attend, leaving Whitehouse and others to scramble for spare “observer” badges through NGOs. Whitehouse is attending as an observer with international association Global Legislators Organisation for a Balanced Environment (GLOBE).

1530 – Concrete jungle: C40 Cities urged on Friday national governments at COP30 to advance a credible global plan to end dependence on fossil fuels, echoing Brazil’s call and responding to climate impacts already hitting cities. Building on COP28 commitments to transition away from fossil fuels, triple renewables, and double energy efficiency by 2030, mayors stressed the need to turn ambition into concrete action through a just and equitable phaseout supported by stronger local-national collaboration. C40 cities have pledged to halve fossil fuel use by 2030, with the highest-emitting countries moving fastest. They are already cutting emissions five times faster than national targets, demonstrating that a fossil-free future is achievable.

1630 – Plans for action: New action plans for the African Union, Caribbean, Chile, Colombia and Mozambique, under the Global Clean Power Alliance (GCPA), have been published on Friday on the UK government website. They aim to identify priority needs and outline targeted support for clean energy transitions, in the countries, including transmission infrastructure and project readiness. These demand-led plans guide collaboration with local partners, the UK government, which co-launched the GCPA, said. Complementing them is a private-finance-endorsed High-Quality Energy Investment Planning Roadmap, designed to help countries mobilise private capital at scale and accelerate global clean energy deployment. At COP30, the UK and Brazil also unveiled new deliverables for the GCPA finance mission, backed by a broad coalition of NGOs, private investors, international organisations, MDBs and other partners committed to advancing energy transitions in developing economies. The alliance was first launched at the G20 Summit in Nov. 2024 by the UK and Brazil, with an initial mission to scale clean energy finance.

1700 – Cheaper SAF agreement – Latin American Airline Abra Group and Japanese company Sumitomo Corporation announced the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding to scale up sustainable aviation fuel. Abra, which owns companies like Brazilian Gol Linhas Aereas, and Sumitomo will establish a Brazil-Japan Joint Crediting Mechanism (JCM) under Article 6.2 of the Paris Agreement to ensure supply of SAF between Abra and Sumitomo. Brazil wants to become a leading global SAF producer via the production of ethanol and biodiesel.

1730 – I want to live by Common Principles: The 10 multilateral development banks in the MDB Nature Working Group have launched an update to the Common Principles for Tracking Nature Finance, which were first released in 2023. They were created in response to the 2021 MDB Joint Statement on Nature, People and Planet, which highlighted the deep connections between poverty reduction, climate action and addressing the drivers of nature loss. The new Joint Statement, published Friday, committed MDBs to embedding nature more fully across their policies, analyses, advice, investments and operations. It also pledged to scale up nature-positive finance and to create stronger methods for tracking such investments across MDB portfolios.

1800 – Big figs: A new Oxford Smith School report shows that a rapid shift to renewables could double energy-sector productivity in low- and middle-income countries within 25 years, delivering GDP gains of around 10% by mid-century. Solar-rich nations such as Burundi, DR Congo, and Mozambique could see particularly strong economic benefits, the researchers said. Renewables raise productivity by generating more electricity per dollar invested and by providing cheaper power, allowing households and industries to operate longer at lower cost. The study found these gains are greatest in the Global South and could help narrow global income disparities. It also shows renewable investment has already boosted GDP in developing countries far more than fossil fuels, adding $1.2 trillion between 2017 and 2022. In Brazil alone, renewables contributed $128 billion. However, the authors stressed that communities benefit only when intentional mechanisms – such as local ownership and community funds – are in place. They also highlighted the importance of distributed renewables to expand access and ensure an inclusive transition.

1800 – BB carbon desk: Banco do Brasil (BB) formally launched its carbon credit desk on Friday, becoming the first Brazilian bank to do so. The bank’s carbon business will rely on three prongs: project origination, commercialisation of credits, and decarbonisation advisory. Currently, BB already has more than 30 projects under development, with the capacity to generate up to 3 mln carbon credits per year, it said.

Here are Carbon Pulse’s latest articles at COP30:

FEATURE – Poor accountability in Article 6.2 reporting hurts market robustness, experts say

Some parties seeking to revisit Article 6.2 guidance in negotiations

New PACM text requests revision to baseline crediting methodology, CDM transition extension

EXCLUSIVE – Brazilian developer, ecological institute partner for restoration carbon projects

Brazil’s Treasury offers loans at 1% per year to attract foreign investment to Amazonian bioeconomy

Japan urged to stop supporting ‘false solutions’ under AZEC

African countries worry metrics for measuring adaptation work will bring extra costs

World Bank, WWF announce ‘Indigenous Bank’ to channel direct carbon credit revenues to communities

Forestry companies identify key ecosystem services for unified nature valuation framework

Fossil fuel lobbyists make up record share of COP attendance, analysis finds

US senator warns CBAM proponents of upcoming Trump opposition

INTERVIEW – Brazilian asset manager eyes ETS rollout as catalyst for expanding carbon market investments

COP30: Paris carbon permanence rules “wolf at the door”, says forestry developer

China, EU steel associations sign deals to align carbon rules

CDR credits emerging as key financing lever to scale CCUS, experts say

LEAF Coalition approves first Caribbean supplier country

BRIEFING – UN Refugee Agency targets $30 mln to pilot carbon credit projects at Uganda, Rwanda camps

Germany unlikely to offer tropical forest funding pledge in Belem -state secretary

By Carbon Pulse’s COP30 team in Belem – news@carbon-pulse.com

title: LanzaJet's New Ethanol-Powered Jet Fuel to Transform Aviation Sustainability in Georgia
description:
A New Era for Aviation Fuel in Georgia LanzaJet’s new facility in Georgia, known as LanzaJet Freedom Pines Fuels, marks the first-ever commercial production of jet fuel derived from ethanol.
The plant’s operations have now reached full capacity, positioning LanzaJet at the forefront of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production.
By using ethanol as a feedstock, LanzaJet’s fuel solution offers substantial greenhouse gas emissions reductions over traditional jet fuel.
When blended with conventional Jet A-1 fuel, it creates a fully certified sustainable aviation fuel that is compatible with existing aircraft and infrastructure.
A Bright Future for Sustainable Aviation LanzaJet’s groundbreaking achievement in Georgia represents a significant milestone in the aviation industry’s shift toward sustainability.
text:
LanzaJet’s New Ethanol-Powered Jet Fuel to Transform Aviation Sustainability in Georgia: All You Need To Know

LanzaJet, the alternative fuels technology company that is marked as a significant player, has achieved a major breakthrough in Soperton, Georgia, which can be regarded as a monumental step for the aviation industry. The firm has made history by being the first-ever to produce jet fuel out of ethanol at the scale of a commercial operation. This new method is not simply a technical success but rather a major leap that will greatly affect the use of eco-friendly travel in the future.

A New Era for Aviation Fuel in Georgia

LanzaJet’s new facility in Georgia, known as LanzaJet Freedom Pines Fuels, marks the first-ever commercial production of jet fuel derived from ethanol. This facility, strategically located in Treutlen County, has successfully achieved ASTM (American Society for Testing and Materials) certification for on-spec jet fuel. The plant’s operations have now reached full capacity, positioning LanzaJet at the forefront of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production.

This development has been years in the making. After 15 years of research, development, and collaboration, LanzaJet’s ethanol-to-jet (ATJ) technology is now fully operational, offering the aviation industry a cleaner and more sustainable alternative to conventional fossil-based jet fuels. With the aviation sector under increasing pressure to reduce its carbon footprint, this new fuel offers a viable, eco-friendly solution.

LanzaJet’s Alcohol-to-Jet Technology

LanzaJet’s innovative Alcohol-to-Jet (ATJ) technology is a game-changer for sustainable aviation. Unlike traditional fossil fuels, which rely on limited oil reserves, LanzaJet’s fuel is derived from widely available ethanol feedstocks. These feedstocks can come from a range of sources, including agricultural residues and recycled carbon from waste. The versatility of this technology means that nations worldwide can tap into their local agricultural resources to produce jet fuel, promoting energy security and reducing reliance on imported fuels.

By using ethanol as a feedstock, LanzaJet’s fuel solution offers substantial greenhouse gas emissions reductions over traditional jet fuel. When blended with conventional Jet A-1 fuel, it creates a fully certified sustainable aviation fuel that is compatible with existing aircraft and infrastructure. This means airlines can start using this cleaner fuel without making costly adjustments to their fleets or operations, further enhancing its appeal.

Impact on Travel and Tourism

This breakthrough will undoubtedly influence the future of air travel. As the aviation industry grapples with its carbon emissions, sustainable aviation fuels like those produced by LanzaJet offer a promising pathway towards more eco-conscious travel. With the aviation industry contributing a significant portion of global CO2 emissions, LanzaJet’s innovation could help reduce the environmental impact of air travel, making it more sustainable for future generations.

For the tourism industry, this means a future where travellers can feel better about the environmental impact of their flights. As more airlines adopt SAF, air travel will become greener, supporting tourism in a more sustainable way. This could encourage eco-minded travellers to choose more environmentally friendly options and contribute to the overall sustainability of the tourism sector.

Georgia’s Role in Leading the Way

LanzaJet’s Freedom Pines Fuels facility is a model for future sustainable aviation fuel production worldwide. With the plant’s successful integration of cutting-edge technologies, it sets a blueprint for other regions to follow suit. This project also highlights the growing importance of regional investments in sustainable technologies and infrastructure, boosting local economies and creating new job opportunities.

The Freedom Pines Fuels facility was developed with an investment of over 300 million USD, employing over 300 people during construction and creating additional long-term jobs. These efforts are not only advancing global aviation but also contributing to the local community in Georgia, which benefits from economic development and energy security brought about by the new facility.

A Bright Future for Sustainable Aviation

LanzaJet’s groundbreaking achievement in Georgia represents a significant milestone in the aviation industry’s shift toward sustainability. With its ethanol-based jet fuel, the company has unlocked a new chapter in aviation, where travel is not only convenient but also more sustainable. As LanzaJet continues to scale its operations, the future of air travel looks greener and more promising than ever.

By providing a scalable and environmentally friendly alternative to traditional aviation fuel, LanzaJet is setting a new standard for the aviation industry, inspiring other countries and companies to follow suit. This development not only benefits the global aviation sector but also paves the way for a more sustainable and responsible travel experience for all.

title: Opinion | Illinois could be soy much more - The Daily Illini
description:
JB Pritzker announced a joint collaborative investment with Avina Clean Hydrogen Inc. to develop a $820 million biofuel aviation fueling plant in southwestern Illinois.
Illinois’ investment comes at a time of increasing climate vulnerability across the United States and the globe.
Illinois is a critical contributor to the efforts of biofuel production.
Currently, soy and corn crops are major contributors to the input of biofuel production.
The SAF project poses a major challenge to the health of Illinois soil, indirectly encouraging monoculture cultivation.
text:
Since Dec. 3, 1818, the sun has set and risen across the state of Illinois. From the urban center of Chicago, to the agricultural cores of Peoria, Champaign and Decatur, to the fields of the southern counties, generations have seen the same sun mark the passing of every day.

Today, Illinois no longer shares the same mark of a new day. In the north, the day ends with the light of opportunity. In the south, the sun sets into the darkness of poverty.

In 2025, Illinois Gov. JB Pritzker announced a joint collaborative investment with Avina Clean Hydrogen Inc. to develop a $820 million biofuel aviation fueling plant in southwestern Illinois. Both parties announced the investment in huge advancements to promote clean energy economies and lead a national industry.

Illinois’ investment comes at a time of increasing climate vulnerability across the United States and the globe. As calls for environmental stability and justice increase, calls for change arise across the U.S.

What is critical about the investment is the location: the agricultural heart of Illinois, home to acres of farmland, the national leader of soy crops and a dominant producer of field corn. Illinois is a critical contributor to the efforts of biofuel production. Yet Pritzker’s policy lacks long-term solvency to protect the true heart of Illinois: our farmers.

The issue with the investment in the sustainable aviation fuel plant, in its simplest form, exists within the goals of the Pritzker administration and actions for environmental sustainability. Nowhere have the interests and environmental justice of Illinois communities been attempted to be protected.

In the status quo, Illinois is home to over 71,000 farms — over 95% of them being family operated. Even when disregarding the scale of operations, family farms are crucial in preserving local ecosystem health. Family farms use less intensive farming practices, leading to less nutrient and soil degradation.

The importance of soil health extends far beyond simply growing crops; a healthy soil holds more organic carbon. When we boost soil health, we reduce carbon dioxide in the atmosphere through carbon being held in the soil, strengthening photosynthesis alongside increased water retention and soil nutrients.

Currently, soy and corn crops are major contributors to the input of biofuel production. When investment in biofuels expands, more operations are going to grow soy — due to easier management and lower production costs — in larger quantities to maximize profits. The issue with this is that when soy is grown more frequently, Soil Organic Carbon decreases, causing soil health to decline and emissions to rise.

The SAF project poses a major challenge to the health of Illinois soil, indirectly encouraging monoculture cultivation. This is critical as operations attempt to invest in a growing industry, projected to be worth $257.61 billion by 2034.

Solvency in the long term is limited for Illinois farmers due to distance decay. One of the premises of the project is entirely designed to benefit large-scale corn and soy monopolies over Illinois farmers, through the dominance of agricultural monopolies and their control of the entire supply chain.

What we see here is a shifted reliance on monopolies to meet higher demands for corn and soy through higher production methods, streamlined through unsustainable and soil-degrading cultivation.

Even if we argue that Illinois farms will be able to keep up with production demands and not be outcompeted by large-scale operations, they will still be placed at an economic disadvantage. As the distance from the market increases, the interaction between the two places decreases, due to local operations remaining more cost-efficient to run.

As infrastructure increases in southwest Illinois, to maximize profit and minimize costs, large operations inherently want to be near the plant. Large-scale operations are further outcompeting Illinois farmers through control of the supply chain and placing localized pressure.

To acknowledge the impacts of wide-scale climate change, the transportation sector is a heavy producer of greenhouse gas emissions. However, the only impacts you see from the Avina plant are the depreciation of Illinoisans’ livelihoods and the sustainability of poverty, not the climate.

One critical factor is true: the biofuel plant is for aviation, a factor that does not justify the impacts on local communities. Major airports are marginal within southern Illinois, making the positive benefits of aviation biofuels not relevant to southern Illinois, nor would they justify the lack of protective policy.

I am not saying that we should avoid investment in clean energy because it has no direct impact on Illinois. We should avoid investments that exacerbate existing inequalities placed on rural constituents, paired with no direct benefits for the community.

Holding Pritzker at his highest ground, you see job growth of roughly 150 permanent positions, critical in any rural economy, temporary or long-term. What you also see is that the lack of skill sets needed for working in the biofuel sector is not transferred over from local rural populations, but instead outsourced to people outside of rural communities.

This is essential as the soy industry is already facing pressures amid the Trump administration tariffs and China’s boycott. Investing in a facility with no protections for rural Illinoisans whose very livelihoods rely on the next harvest exposes them to unemployment and poverty.

What I am not doing is disagreeing with Pritzker’s policy and the SAF project’s long-term goals. I am, however, disagreeing with the implementation and the decimation of the backbone of the State of Illinois: multi-generational family farms.

While sustainability, energy and fuel investment are essential for our state and nation in the long term, the SAF project, today, does not provide the change that all can benefit from.

To encourage proper sustainability, Pritzker needs to change his priorities from profit to his people. Constituents who are further isolated from opportunity to advance the goals of wealthy agricultural conglomerates.

For once, the emphasis of environmental action and justice needs to prioritize the sustainability of our current generation, not the future. To create true change and solvency, our farmers need to be protected rather than threatened.

Samantha is a freshman in LAS.

title: Brazil And Japan Forge Bold Green Alliance, Abra And Sumitomo Ignite A Breakthrough ...
description:
Their primary goal is to advance the implementation of a Brazil–Japan Joint Crediting Mechanism (JCM), developed under Article 6.2 of the Paris Agreement.
For Abra and Sumitomo, establishing the JCM in Brazil represents the essential step toward enabling a long-term offtake agreement for Sustainable Aviation Fuel.
Meeting Soaring Global Demand for Sustainable Aviation Fuel The aviation industry is entering a crucial era.
Mutual Gains for Governments, Producers and Passengers The Abra–Sumitomo collaboration generates unique benefits for both countries.
As the aviation sector moves into a defining decade, the Abra–Sumitomo partnership stands out as a forward-looking blueprint for cross-border cooperation, climate-aligned investment and large-scale deployment of sustainable aviation technologies.
text:
Abra Group, the powerhouse behind major Latin American aviation brands Gol, Avianca and Wamos Air, has taken a decisive step toward reshaping the future of sustainable air travel. The group has signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with Sumitomo Corporation do Brasil, a key subsidiary of Japan’s global trading giant Sumitomo Corporation, to accelerate the creation and deployment of industry-ready decarbonization solutions for aviation.

The agreement marks a strategic alliance between two regions with increasingly aligned climate ambitions. It also signals a new phase in the development of Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) in Brazil, a country widely regarded as one of the world’s most capable future producers.

A Partnership Designed to Fast-Track Emissions Reductions

The MoU establishes a joint framework for Abra – represented in Brazil through Gol Linhas Aéreas – and Sumitomo to coordinate deeply with government bodies, regulators and private-sector stakeholders in both Brazil and Japan. Their primary goal is to advance the implementation of a Brazil–Japan Joint Crediting Mechanism (JCM), developed under Article 6.2 of the Paris Agreement.

The JCM is a bilateral carbon-offset system introduced by Japan in 2011 to support low-carbon projects in developing regions. In exchange, Japan receives a portion of the generated emission-reduction credits, helping the country meet its domestic climate targets while accelerating climate-positive investments abroad.

For Abra and Sumitomo, establishing the JCM in Brazil represents the essential step toward enabling a long-term offtake agreement for Sustainable Aviation Fuel. By aligning both nations’ climate policy frameworks, the two companies aim to remove one of the most significant barriers to SAF expansion: the need for reliable long-term financing and guaranteed market demand.

Meeting Soaring Global Demand for Sustainable Aviation Fuel

The aviation industry is entering a crucial era. Global demand for SAF is projected to reach nearly 400 million tons by 2050, driven by international decarbonization commitments, emerging regulatory pressure and the aviation sector’s urgent need to reduce its footprint.

Developed economies with minimal access to feedstock – including Japan, Singapore and several European nations – are already bracing for severe supply constraints. SAF production requires large quantities of biomass or renewable feed materials, making resource-rich countries like Brazil pivotal to the global energy transition.

Brazil has long been recognized as an agricultural and biofuel leader, with decades of experience in ethanol, biodiesel and renewable energy technologies. This positions the country uniquely well to become a central hub for SAF production. Yet, despite having the natural and industrial advantages, large-scale SAF development faces persistent financial challenges. High production costs, investment risks, and the need to preserve affordable domestic air travel for Brazilian consumers remain critical concerns.

The introduction of the Brazil–Japan JCM could provide the missing bridge. The framework would unlock new financial flows, lower market-entry risks for producers and create a stable foundation for long-term SAF supply agreements. Airlines in both countries would benefit, while Brazil would expand a new renewable-energy export market without compromising its domestic aviation accessibility.

Mutual Gains for Governments, Producers and Passengers

The Abra–Sumitomo collaboration generates unique benefits for both countries. Japan gains access to competitively priced SAF sourced from a reliable partner with vast renewable potential. Brazil secures investment, technology and market guarantees that support local producers and job creation, while reinforcing its leadership role in the global renewable-energy landscape.

Brazilian airlines, including Gol, stand to benefit from increased SAF availability within their domestic market—an essential advantage as global regulations tighten and consumer pressure for sustainable travel intensifies. Passengers across both nations ultimately gain from a cleaner, more responsible aviation ecosystem with long-term safeguards for affordability and operational continuity.

Strengthening Latin America’s Sustainability Voice Ahead of COP30

The signing of this MoU comes at a critical moment. With the world turning its attention to Latin America as Brazil prepares to host COP30, sustainability partnerships of this scale signal the region’s growing influence in shaping global climate solutions.

For Abra Group, the agreement reinforces its commitment to responsible aviation policies that safeguard connectivity, economic opportunity, environmental responsibility and social progress across Latin America. By championing innovation and aligning with global partners, the group aims not only to transform its own operations but also to set a benchmark for regional and international airlines.

As the aviation sector moves into a defining decade, the Abra–Sumitomo partnership stands out as a forward-looking blueprint for cross-border cooperation, climate-aligned investment and large-scale deployment of sustainable aviation technologies. Through collaboration, innovation and strategic policy alignment, the two organizations are helping shape a future where growth in air travel can coexist with meaningful climate action.

Maria Del Mar Whittaker, Chief Corporate Responsibility Officer, Abra Group, said: “At a time

when financing for SAF projects is particularly challenging due to market uncertainties, demand

constraints and evolving regulations, creative solutions that leverage the strengths of different global

regions are the best path forward. This joint initiative represents an important step towards global

climate alignment, connecting Japan’s commitment to decarbonization with Brazil’s unique capacity

for SAF production and its need for affordable aviation connectivity.

title: Boeing Seals Major Deal With Charm Industrial To Store CO2 Underground - Carbon Herald
description:
As the commercial aviation sector struggles to transition away from fossil fuels, Boeing is turning to underground carbon storage as a cost-effective alternative to sustainable jet fuels.
Charm and Boeing charting a CO2 removal course The deal could indicate renewed demand for carbon removal within aviation.
For startups like Charm, this creates a lucrative market for carbon removal credits.
For Boeing, the new agreement underscores a pragmatic strategy: combine emerging carbon removal technologies with long-term investments in sustainable aviation fuel.
By leveraging Charm’s underground storage approach, Boeing hopes to bridge the gap between current emissions realities and future green fuel adoption.
text:
Boeing has entered a landmark agreement with climate startup Charm Industrial to sequester 100,000 metric tons of carbon dioxide, marking one of the aerospace giant’s most ambitious sustainability initiatives to date.

As the commercial aviation sector struggles to transition away from fossil fuels, Boeing is turning to underground carbon storage as a cost-effective alternative to sustainable jet fuels.

Charm’s process begins with agricultural and forestry residues, which are converted into a dense liquid known as bio-oil through a thermal treatment. Instead of being burned, the bio-oil is injected deep underground, including into depleted oil wells, where it can remain stable for centuries.

The approach provides a tangible solution for companies facing growing pressure to offset emissions while more scalable fuel alternatives remain years away.

Charm and Boeing charting a CO2 removal course

The deal could indicate renewed demand for carbon removal within aviation. 2023 saw a deal for the removal of 400,000 tonnes of CO2 between Occidental (through its subsidiary 1PointFive) and Airbus and there have been others involving carriers but not enough to call this a functioning market.

Analysts estimate the industry will need at least $60 billion in offsets by 2050 to achieve net-zero emissions targets. For startups like Charm, this creates a lucrative market for carbon removal credits.

Charm previously sold 112,000 credits to advance market commitment Frontier for roughly $53 million, but the company aims to dramatically cut costs from $470 per ton to around $50 per ton, potentially unlocking broader adoption.

For Boeing, the new agreement underscores a pragmatic strategy: combine emerging carbon removal technologies with long-term investments in sustainable aviation fuel.

By leveraging Charm’s underground storage approach, Boeing hopes to bridge the gap between current emissions realities and future green fuel adoption. The partnership could provide a fresh signal to the broader aviation industry that one of the best ways to decarbonize should involve more carbon removal.

title: The Booming Future of Sustainable Aviation Fuel Industry - Investors Hangout
description:
Sustainable Aviation Fuel Market Overview The Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) sector is gaining momentum in the global marketplace, prompting serious attention from investors and stakeholders alike.
Challenges to Overcome Despite the rapid expansion and development, the sustainable aviation fuel market faces its share of challenges.
Market Segmentation Breakdown The sustainable aviation fuel market is categorized based on various factors such as fuel type, aircraft type, technology used, platform, and region: Fuel Type: Key segments include biofuel, hydrogen fuel, power-to-liquid fuel, and gas-to-liquid.
Market Dynamics and Future Outlook As we look forward, the dynamics of the sustainable aviation fuel market will continue to evolve.
The increasing number of airlines entering procurement agreements for sustainable aviation fuel projects reflects positively on the market's future.
text:
Sustainable Aviation Fuel Market Overview

The Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) sector is gaining momentum in the global marketplace, prompting serious attention from investors and stakeholders alike. As a renewable alternative to traditional jet fuels sourced from fossil fuels, SAF plays a significant role in the aviation industry's drive towards achieving sustainability and reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

Remarkable Growth Projections

According to recent analyses, the sustainable aviation fuel market was valued at approximately USD 3.94 billion in the recent past, with impressive projections forecasting its growth at a staggering CAGR of 57.50%. By a future date, the market could reach an impressive value of USD 149.10 billion. This stunning growth rate highlights the urgent need for environmentally friendly solutions within aviation.

Key Growth Drivers in the Industry

Several factors are fueling the rise of SAF. The growing pressure on the aviation sector to comply with stringent carbon emission regulations is a primary catalyst driving this transition. Airlines are now taking ambitious steps towards sustainability, with leading carriers pledging to achieve net-zero emissions by a specific timeline. This commitment often includes substantial investment in SAF production and the establishment of long-term procurement agreements to secure supply, thereby stoking the flames of continuous industry demand.

Impact of Technological Advancements

Technological innovations in the production of sustainable aviation fuels are also acting as a significant growth driver. Several production pathways, such as hydroprocessed esters and fatty acids (HEFA), Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FT), and Alcohol-to-Jet (ATJ) processes, are being refined, improving efficiency and scalability. This continuous enhancement in technology results in lowering production costs and making SAF more competitive with traditional fuels.

Challenges to Overcome

Despite the rapid expansion and development, the sustainable aviation fuel market faces its share of challenges. One significant hurdle is the competition for sustainable feedstocks used in fuel production. Scarcity of such feedstocks, including agricultural waste and residual oils, poses a threat to supply reliability and production capabilities. Additionally, the underdeveloped infrastructure for SAF production jeopardizes its positive growth trajectory.

Market Segmentation Breakdown

The sustainable aviation fuel market is categorized based on various factors such as fuel type, aircraft type, technology used, platform, and region:

Fuel Type: Key segments include biofuel, hydrogen fuel, power-to-liquid fuel, and gas-to-liquid. Among these, the biofuel segment prominently dominates the market due to its broader adoption and availability.

Aircraft Type: The market is segmented into fixed wings, rotorcraft, and others. Fixed wings dominate the market share, being critical for cargo and commercial aviation.

Technology: Divided into HEFA-SPK, FT-SPK, HFS-SIP, and ATJ-SPK technologies, the HEFA-SPK segment claims the largest market share, attributed to its extensive supply chains and cost-effectiveness.

Platform: The major platforms include commercial aircraft, regional transport, military aviation, general aviation, and unmanned aerial vehicles, with the commercial segment dominating due to high operational fuel requirements.

Region: Geographically, North America leads the market, attributed to strong airline commitments towards SAF and substantial breakthroughs in production technology.

Market Dynamics and Future Outlook

As we look forward, the dynamics of the sustainable aviation fuel market will continue to evolve. Regulatory frameworks are expected to enforce stricter requirements that will encourage fuel suppliers to adopt SAF more broadly. For instance, various European policies aim to ensure a specific percentage of SAF in fuel blends, thereby promoting its gradual integration into mainstream aviation.

The increasing number of airlines entering procurement agreements for sustainable aviation fuel projects reflects positively on the market's future. Airline companies are keen on mitigating emissions through effective utilization of renewable fuels. As technologies advance and efficiencies improve, expectations are that SAF will become more competitive in pricing compared to traditional fossil fuels in the next few years.

Frequently Asked Questions

What is sustainable aviation fuel?

Sustainable aviation fuel is a renewable alternative to traditional jet fuel that significantly reduces lifecycle carbon emissions and can be produced from various renewable resources.

What are the key factors driving the growth of the sustainable aviation fuel market?

The primary drivers include the aviation industry's commitment to reducing carbon emissions, advancements in fuel production technology, and regulatory pressures that mandate sustainable practices.

How is the sustainable aviation fuel market segmented?

The market is segmented by fuel type, aircraft type, technology, platform, and geographical region, each showcasing unique growth attributes and dynamics.

Which regions are at the forefront of the sustainable aviation fuel market?

North America and Europe are leading regions in the sustainable aviation fuel market, showcasing significant airline commitments and strong regulatory support for renewable aviation fuels.

What companies are major players in this market?

Key players in the sustainable aviation fuel market include Neste, World Energy, and Gevo Inc., among others, which are leading innovations and production capabilities in this sector.

Jetex Milan will boast a unique position in Europe at less than seven kilometers from the city center.
In 2023, the airport took a major step forward in reducing emissions and becoming the first SAF business aviation airport in Italy.
- END - About Jetex: An award-winning global leader in executive aviation, Jetex is recognized for delivering flexible, best-in-class trip support solutions to customers worldwide.
The company caters to both owners and operators of business jets for corporate, commercial and personal air travel.
text:
Jetex Arrives in Milan

Dubai, Nov. 14, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Jetex, a global leader in private aviation, has announced its expansion in Italy with the opening of Jetex Milan in early 2026.

Milan Linate Prime Airport is renowned for its excellence in business jet and helicopter services and charter flights, and the arrival of Jetex is aimed to cement its reputation as Europe’s leading business aviation hub.

Jetex Milan will boast a unique position in Europe at less than seven kilometers from the city center. The new Milano Linate Prime terminal will offer a different luxurious lounges welcome award-winning hospitality as well as well-appointed facilities to ensure each guest enjoys a seamless and personalised experience.

“We are proud to add Milan to the Jetex list of destinations. Milan is a key business and leisure destination in Europe, and we are entering the destination at a historical moment in anticipation of the traffic peak foreseen during the Milan-Cortina 2026 Olympics”, said Adel Mardini, Founder & CEO of Jetex.

International events like the F1 Grand Prix and the Milan Fashion Week have been catalysts of business aviation traffic in Milan with record numbers of visitors and peaks of more than 300 daily movements.

“Thanks to its growing international prominence, Milan has become one of the leading destinations for business aviation, as confirmed by recent traffic data at the Milano Prime facilities, with over 27,600 business aviation movements recorded up to September 2025. The upcoming Linate Prime terminal expansion, scheduled ahead of the 2026 Winter Olympic Games, will add approximately 2,400 square meters of new lounges and passenger service areas, further enhancing comfort and operational efficiency. We are therefore delighted with Jetex’s decision to expand its presence in Milan, joining other prestigious companies that have chosen to operate permanently from Milano Prime Airports”, commented Chiara Dorigotti, CEO of SEA Prime.

In 2023, the airport took a major step forward in reducing emissions and becoming the first SAF business aviation airport in Italy. Building on this success, Jetex Milan will expand the company’s sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) network through offering SAF to more private jet customers.

- END -

About Jetex:

An award-winning global leader in executive aviation, Jetex is recognized for delivering flexible, best-in-class trip support solutions to customers worldwide. Jetex provides exceptional private terminals (FBOs), aircraft fueling, ground handling and global trip planning. The company caters to both owners and operators of business jets for corporate, commercial and personal air travel. To find out more about Jetex, visit www.jetex.com and follow us on Instagram, Twitter, Facebook, and LinkedIn.

text:
Main Menu

AviTrader sponsorship ad

Air Algérie receives first Airbus A330-900

Air Algérie has taken delivery of its first Airbus A330-900, marking a significant milestone in the airline’s long-term expansion strategy. The new aircraft will support growth from Algiers by enabling the launch of additional transatlantic and Asian routes.

Air Algérie’s aircraft is configured in a three-class layout, featuring 18 full-flat Business-Class seats, 24 Premium-Economy seats and 266 seats in Economy.

Passengers will experience Airbus’ Airspace cabin, known for its improved sense of space, larger overhead bins, modern lighting and access to the latest in-flight entertainment and connectivity systems.

As part of its fleet modernisation, Air Algérie plans to establish itself as a regional centre of excellence for the A330neo. The airline will further develop its maintenance and repair capabilities and create a dedicated maintenance training centre to support the aircraft type.

At the end of October 2025, the A330 family had won over 1,900 firm orders from more than 130 customers worldwide. As with all Airbus aircraft, the A330neo is already able to operate with up to 50% sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). Airbus is targeting to have its aircraft up to 100% SAF-capable by 2030.

title: Elastomeric seals for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) - Aerospace Manufacturing and Design
description:
The ASTM D7566 standard outlines eight approved SAF pathways, enabling the production of sustainable fuels tailored to both environmental goals and fuel performance requirements.
Advanced materials like FKM seals provide a reliable solution across SAF blends, ensuring safety and performance without compromising sustainability goals.
Weakening: Prolonged exposure to dry-out conditions or fuel switching (e.g., from conventional jet fuel to SAF) led to reduced sealing performance and dimensional instability.
The cost impact would be from having to replace nitrile seals with the FKM seals due to the higher cost of FKM material.
As mentioned earlier nitrile seals require some aromatic content, so the blending of aromatics or switching to FKM seals would be a cost consideration.
text:
The following offered responses to Aerospace Manufacturing and Design’s questions:

Dr. Ronald R Campbell, PhD, Senior Technical Advisor, Greene Tweed

Becky Petry, Applications Engineer, Greene Tweed

Andrew Clarke, CEng, Applications Engineer — Sealing Systems, Greene Tweed

What are the differences in various types of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and how do these variants affect common elastomers?

Sustainable Aviation Fuels (SAFs) are renewable alternatives to traditional jet fuels, intended to reduce carbon emissions. SAFs are produced from a variety of renewable feedstocks, including biomass, algae, animal fats, vegetable oils, and agricultural residues like corn stalks. The ASTM D7566 standard outlines eight approved SAF pathways, enabling the production of sustainable fuels tailored to both environmental goals and fuel performance requirements.

Within SAF, there are different formulations, including Synthetic Aromatic Kerosene (SAK) and Synthetic Paraffinic Kerosene (SPK). These variants differ primarily in their aromatic content [benzene (ring) hydrocarbons], which plays a vital role in determining their compatibility with elastomers commonly used in aerospace fuel systems:

SAK contains a high level of aromatics, which are essential for maintaining the performance of certain elastomers, such as those used in seals and gaskets. Aromatics help elastomers retain their flexibility and prevent excessive swelling or weakening.

SPK has no aromatic content, making it a cleaner-burning fuel. However, its lack of aromatics can lead to challenges with elastomer compatibility, such as swelling or reduced sealing performance.

Both SAK and SPK formulations play a critical role in the adoption of SAF. While SAK’s high aromatic content supports compatibility with traditional elastomers, SPK offers a cleaner-burning alternative with fewer emissions but requires careful consideration of elastomer performance. Advanced materials like FKM seals provide a reliable solution across SAF blends, ensuring safety and performance without compromising sustainability goals. As the aviation industry continues its transition toward greener fuels, understanding the nuances of SAF formulations and their impact on materials will be key to a seamless shift toward more sustainable skies.

Which form of SAF – SAK or SPK – is more in use or likely to come into use?

Currently, SPK is more widely adopted and is set to play a key role in the future of aviation. The diversity of feedstocks approved under ASTM D7566 highlights the broad range of sources available for SPK production. Aircraft manufacturers are also making strides toward sustainability, with plans to design aircraft capable of operating on 100% SPK by 2030. Certain SPK feedstocks are already proving to be the dominant choice for SAF.

We worked with Virant to source and test SAK (which is 97% aromatic) – a material with a high aromatic content (97%) derived from algae. This product was specifically developed to blend with approximately 80% SPK, ensuring the correct aromatic balance needed for a drop-in fuel compatible with nitrile seals exposed to jet fuel. While SAK is not intended to be used as a standalone fuel, it serves as a critical blending component. A mixture of 80% SPK and 20% SAK creates a 100% sustainable fuel option, eliminating the need for petroleum-based jet fuel while maintaining performance and reliability.

Where are elastomer seals used and for what purpose?

In aerospace applications, elastomer seals are critical components used in fuel systems, hydraulic systems, and engines to prevent leaks and ensure safety. Their primary purpose is to create a reliable barrier that prevents leaks, withstands elevated temperatures, and resists chemical degradation.

What material used in commercial applications underperforms with SAF and in what ways (swelling, weakening) and under what conditions?

Fluorosilicone elastomers (FVMQ), such as Greene Tweed’s 409 compound, showed underperformance in certain conditions:

Hardness Change: FVMQ materials exhibited greater and/or inconsistent hardness reduction when exposed to SAF fluids.

Weakening: Prolonged exposure to dry-out conditions or fuel switching (e.g., from conventional jet fuel to SAF) led to reduced sealing performance and dimensional instability.

Based on the variance in results between the different types of SAFs used, we recommend further application testing of any FVMQ compound in the specific SAF fluid intended for use. In contrast, under the same test conditions Greene Tweed’s fluorine-based elastomers (FKM compounds 665, 731, and 772) demonstrated good compatibility and consistent performance.

How widespread is the use of seals that use this material?

FVMQ (the material which underperformed during testing) represents a choice for static fuel applications that require good sealing performance over a broad temperature range. Few material options were historically available that could offer excellent levels of sealing performance at very cold temperatures (i.e. below -54°C or -65°F). However, newer grades of FKM material are also capable of performing well at these cold temperatures.

Are substitute materials available (and approved by the FAA, EASA, etc.) to replace the underperforming seal materials?

As mentioned above, newer grades of FKM material (notably those compliant against AMS7379 and AMS7410 industry specifications) can perform well at very cold temperatures. As such, they can meet the operating temperature envelope that only an FVMQ material can offer. In addition, FKM materials also typically cost somewhat less than FVMQs. FKM materials can therefore represent an attractive alternative to an FVMQ material.

It should be noted that if a type of sealing product is replaced within an aircraft system, it is the responsibility of aircraft system manufacturers to qualify the replacement and demonstrate an equivalent level of performance.

Do FKM seals cost more?

The cost impact would be from having to replace nitrile seals with the FKM seals due to the higher cost of FKM material. As mentioned earlier nitrile seals require some aromatic content, so the blending of aromatics or switching to FKM seals would be a cost consideration.

Is the supply chain for the substitute material challenged?

The supply chain for advanced elastomer materials like FKM is currently stable, however, fluctuations are always possible depending on factors like increased demand. Greene Tweed’s global manufacturing and distribution network ensures a reliable supply of high-performance elastomers to meet industry needs.

What is Greene Tweed’s expertise in supplying elastomers for SAF (can cover research, testing, verification, manufacturing or distribution strengths).

As a global leader in advanced materials and high-performance solutions, with decades of experience in elastomer technology, our expertise spans multiple areas, including advanced material science capabilities in research and development.

We follow this with comprehensive testing and verification protocols to ensure our materials meet or exceed industry standards. For this particular application, we conducted a comprehensive study to evaluate the compatibility of fluorine-based elastomer seals with various SAF blends, including SPK and SAK. The seals were tested under accelerated aerospace conditions, such as temperatures up to 120°C and prolonged SAF exposure, to ensure their reliability in real-world applications.

Our manufacturing facilities also enable us to produce high-quality elastomers at scale, while our robust global distribution network ensures efficient delivery to customers worldwide.

Proving seal compatibility with SAFs through rigorous testing ensures that existing aircraft and systems can safely transition to these fuels without costly overhauls, paving the way for a more sustainable future in aviation while maintaining safety and reliability standards.

title: As part of The Aviation Challenge 2025, Kenya Airways operated its first intra-African flight ...
description:
As part of The Aviation Challenge 2025, Kenya Airways operated its first intra-African flight using 50% Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) attributes between Nairobi and Cape Town.
On this flight, Kenya Airways also tested upcycled onboard materials, reusable cutlery, and locally sourced foods, proving how small innovations can make a big impact.

title: Singapore SAF Levy Helps Spark Local Production | Energy Intelligence
description:
Two new sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) plants on either side of the narrow strait between Southern Malaysia and Singapore made progress this week, just as the Singapore government finalized plans for a new SAF levy starting next year.
Singapore is aiming to use 1% SAF at Changi airport next year, rising to 3%-5% by 2030.
SAF purchases will be financed entirely via the levy on passenger air fares and cargo fees rather than by the airlines.

title: AM Green to invest ₹10K cr in Andhra Pradesh for sustainable aviation fuel | Industry News
description:
The government of Andhra Pradesh and AM Green Group on Friday signed memoranda of understanding (MoUs) to set up multiple 2G biorefineries to produce cost-effective green hydrocarbons and 180 KTPA (kilotonnes per annum) sustainable aviation fuel with an investment of Rs 10,000 crore.
AM Green Group has enabled a multitude of decarbonisation solutions for global and Indian markets by combining innovative technologies with robust business models to create new products and solutions.
The deal was signed on the first day of the mega CII partnership summit held in Visakhapatnam.

title: ENOC Powers Aviation Sustainability At Dubai | decarbonfuse.com
description:
ENOC Group, a leading integrated global energy player, is reaffirming its commitment to sustainability and innovation at the 19th edition of the Dubai Airshow.
Collaboration with Jetex highlights ENOC’s role in advancing low-emission private aviation through Sustainable Aviation Fuel.
Dubai, UAE: ENOC Group, a leading integrated global energy player, is reaffirming its commitment to sustainability and innovation at the 19th edition of the Dubai Airshow.
As part of its broader strategy to support the energy sector’s transition to net-zero, ENOC is supplying Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) to Jetex customer aircraft during the event.
In parallel, the Group is presenting its latest clean energy technologies and partnerships at Dubai Airports world-first Sustainability Showcase.
text:
ENOC Group, a leading integrated global energy player, is reaffirming its commitment to sustainability and innovation at the 19th edition of the Dubai Airshow.

Collaboration with Jetex highlights ENOC’s role in advancing low-emission private aviation through Sustainable Aviation Fuel.

Dubai, UAE: ENOC Group, a leading integrated global energy player, is reaffirming its commitment to sustainability and innovation at the 19th edition of the Dubai Airshow. As part of its broader strategy to support the energy sector’s transition to net-zero, ENOC is supplying Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) to Jetex customer aircraft during the event. In parallel, the Group is presenting its latest clean energy technologies and partnerships at Dubai Airports world-first Sustainability Showcase.

>> In Other News: [x](x)

“At ENOC, we remain focused on delivering reliable, efficient, and future-ready energy solutions that align with national priorities such as the Dubai Clean Energy Strategy 2050 and the Dubai Green Mobility Strategy 2030,” said Hussain Sultan Lootah, Acting CEO of ENOC Group. “Our participation at the Dubai Airshow reflects our commitment to enabling sustainable aviation, advancing mobility, and driving scalable innovations which contribute to shaping the future of aerospace.”

ENOC’s SAF deployment during the Airshow supports Jetex’s efforts to reduce carbon emissions from its operating flights. As a global leader in private aviation, Jetex’s collaboration with ENOC reflects a shared vision to accelerate the adoption of low-emission fuel alternatives and set new benchmarks for sustainability in the aviation sector.

Adel Mardini, Founder & CEO of Jetex, said: “Our environment strategy focuses on reducing carbon emissions, recycling, and adapting the latest green technologies across the global network, and we are pleased to be able to supply our aircraft with sustainable aviation fuel at the Dubai Airshow.”

As part of its participation at Dubai Airshow 2025, ENOC is also showcasing its broader clean energy initiatives, including the partnership with Dubai Airports to transition ground operations from conventional fuels to biodiesel. ENOC’s biofuel tanker, dedicated to transporting biodiesel, stands as a key highlight demonstrating the Group’s commitment to low-carbon logistics and infrastructure innovation.

title: What's on in the Lords 17-21 November - UK Parliament
description:
What's on in the Lords 17-21 November 14 November 2025 Nov 14 2025 Questions Lords members press the government on artificial intelligence legislation, de-escalating the conflict in Ukraine, the annual number serious injuries and deaths on the roads, and compensating victims of child grooming scandals.
Watch chamber business and Lords committee meetings on Parliament TV.
Subscribe to the House of Lords newsletter Sign up and receive weekly updates on the latest news stories, draft law scrutiny, committee work and discussions happening in the Lords.

Subscribe now (external site) Lords enquiry service Contact the House of Lords enquiry service with questions about the Lords: Telephone: 0800 223 0855 (Freephone) or 020 7219 3107 Email: hlinfo@parliament.uk Text Relay: 18001 7219 3107
text:
What's on in the Lords 17-21 November

14 November 2025

Nov

14

2025

Questions

Lords members press the government on artificial intelligence legislation, de-escalating the conflict in Ukraine, the annual number serious injuries and deaths on the roads, and compensating victims of child grooming scandals.

Bills

A debate on the key purpose of the Sustainable Aviation Fuel Bill, and consideration of Commons amendments to the Employment Rights Bill are on the agenda.

Members will also undertake line by line scrutiny of the Crime and Policing Bill, Tobacco and Vapes Bill, the Diego Garcia Military Base and British Indian Ocean Territory Bill, and the Terminally Ill Adults (End of Life) Bill.

A 'tidy up' of the Border Security, Asylum and Immigration Bill, and the Animal Welfare (Import of Dogs, Cats and Ferrets) Bill will also take place.

Debates

On Thursday, four short debates are scheduled on medical nuclear radioisotopes, the role of private equity in the UK economy, plastic recycling, and the impact of litter on canal towpaths.

Committees

On Tuesday, the Industry and Regulators Committee, conducting an inquiry into regulators and growth, will hear from Dan Elliot, Founder and Director at Frontier Economics.

Also on Tuesday, the Economic Affairs Committee will hear from Dr Xavier Debrun, the Head of Economics and Research at National Bank of Belgium, regarding an inquiry into the UK's fiscal framework.

On Wednesday, the International Relations and Defence Committee will hear from Stephen Doughty MP, Minister of State at the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office.

Read on for more.

Monday

From 2.30pm

Questions

recognising and supporting children with dyscalculia

proposed artificial intelligence legislation

impact of imposing inheritance tax on unused pensions and death benefits

increase in teachers of music, drama, art and design, and dance.

Legislation

The Border Security, Asylum and Immigration Bill will be 'tidied up', and consideration of Commons changes to the Employment Rights Bill are on the agenda.

Members will also undertake line-by-line scrutiny of the Crime and Policing Bill and the Tobacco and Vapes Bill.

Tuesday

From 2.30pm

Questions

publication of the Independent Review in Carer's Allowance overpayments report

Ministry of Defence maximising UK-manufactured products in procurement decisions

consolidation of election law

fourth questioned to be determined.

Legislation

Members will begin line-by-line scrutiny of the Diego Garcia Military Base and British Indian Ocean Territory Bill.

Wednesday

From 3pm

Questions

discussions with the US government on the conflict in Ukraine

annual number serious injuries and deaths on the roads

hydrogen and fuel cell industry

fourth questioned to be determined.

Legislation

Members will continue detailed scrutiny of the Crime and Policing Bill.

Thursday

From 11am

Questions

water and sewerage companies as consultees on infrastructure projects

South Western Railway: performance since nationalisation

compensation to victims of child grooming

fourth questioned to be determined.

Legislation

Members will debate the core principles and purpose of the Sustainable Aviation Fuel Bill.

Debates

domestic manufacture of medical nuclear radioisotopes

the role of private equity in the UK economy

plastic recycling

the impact of litter on canal towpaths.

Friday

From 10am

Legislation

Members will 'tidy up' the Animal Welfare (Import of Dogs, Cats and Ferrets) Bill and continue line by line examination of the Terminally Ill Adults (End of Life) Bill.

Watch

Questions, debates and scrutiny of legislation are streamed live online for free. Watch chamber business and Lords committee meetings on Parliament TV.

Read

All business in the House of Lords chamber and in Grand Committee is transcribed and available to read from around three hours after it happens. Read it free online in Lords Hansard.

Follow on X

Visit @UKHouseofLords on X for highlights of each day’s work in the House.

Follow the hashtag #HouseOfLords for what’s happening, or #LordsQs for details of questions put to the government at the start of business Monday to Thursday.

Other social media

Follow the House of Lords on Bluesky, Facebook, Flickr, Instagram, LinkedIn, YouTube and Threads for highlights, photos and videos from the UK Parliament’s second chamber.

Subscribe to the House of Lords newsletter

Sign up and receive weekly updates on the latest news stories, draft law scrutiny, committee work and discussions happening in the Lords.

Image credit: House of Lords
